title: How to Shave Your Legs for the First Time

steps.title: Use female razors.
steps.content: Use female razors. Female razors come with a rounded head and a curved handle that are made to help you access those trickier spots behind your knees and around your ankles. Despite the name, anyone can use female razors, not just women. They are not designed to work specifically for women's bodies.

steps.title: Pick a razor system.
steps.content: Pick a razor system. Razor systems are razors that have a permanent handle and a disposable razor head. You can buy razor cartridges to replace worn out razor heads. While these razors can be more expensive, they often have built in moisturizers or lubricants, such as vitamin E, that are great if you have sensitive skin.

steps.title: Choose a disposable razor.
steps.content: Choose a disposable razor. Disposable razors are a great idea if your skin isn’t sensitive or if you want to just pitch the entire razor when it’s worn out. Disposable razors also tend to be a cheaper option.

steps.title: Choose a multi-blade razor.
steps.content: Choose a multi-blade razor. It’s important to choose a razor with more than one blade, since single blade razors are more likely to drag against the skin. Three blades is typical for a razor. [1] X Research source Razors come with as many as six blades! You should experiment and see what number of blades feel best on your skin.

steps.title: Purchase shaving cream or gel.
steps.content: Purchase shaving cream or gel. You need a lathering agent to help the razor glide easily over your skin. Using a shaving cream or gel will help prevent razor burn, or red bumps that are caused by shaving. Shaving cream also reduces the number of nicks you give yourself shaving. Don’t want to purchase shaving cream? Hair conditioner is a great alternative that’s also much cheaper. [2] X Research source If you have sensitive skin, avoid shaving creams that contain alcohol. The alcohol will dry out your skin.

steps.title: Shave at the end of your shower.
steps.content: Shave at the end of your shower. The warm water of your shower softens your leg hair and opens your follicles, which makes shaving easier. Shave after your legs have been exposed to the water of your shower for about 10-15 minutes. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wash off your legs with soap and water.
steps.content: Wash off your legs with soap and water. Before you begin shaving, wash off your legs with soap and warm water to prevent any infections. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Apply your shaving cream to your entire leg.
steps.content: Apply your shaving cream to your entire leg. Liberally apply shaving cream with your hands, making sure it’s fully covering the area of your leg that you want to shave. If you’re looking to really get a close shave, apply shaving cream with a shaving brush, which will help raise the hair up, so it’s better exposed during shaving.

steps.title: Hold your razor lightly at a 30 degree angle to your leg.
steps.content: Hold your razor lightly at a 30 degree angle to your leg. You’ll want to hold your razor at an angle that feels good to you, which is probably around 30 degrees. Make sure you’re holding the razor with the handle pointed down towards your toes.

steps.title: Shave with the grain.
steps.content: Shave with the grain. Shaving with the grain, or down the leg, is best for your first shave. Because your leg hair will be longer, going with the grain of your hair will reduce the possibility of irritation. Shaving against the grain, or shaving up the leg, is okay once your leg hair is shorter. If you have sensitive skin, always shave with the grain, or down the leg. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Go gently over the knee and ankle.
steps.content: Go gently over the knee and ankle. Shaving around the knee and ankle are the trickiest parts of shaving your legs for the first time. Go slowly and apply less pressure as you shave over these areas, so you don’t cut yourself. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse your razor between strokes.
steps.content: Rinse your razor between strokes. Be sure to rinse your razor every 2 to 3 strokes. If you continue shaving with shaving cream or hair that’s clogging the blades, you’ll be more likely to cut yourself. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse your legs with cold water.
steps.content: Rinse your legs with cold water. After you’ve finished shaving, rinse your legs off with cool water, which will close up your pores. For more tips about shaving your legs, check out the "How do I get rid of strawberry legs fast? It's giving me the ick." forum page.

steps.title: Apply moisturizer or oil regularly after shaving.
steps.content: Apply moisturizer or oil regularly after shaving. After shaving you should always apply a moisturizing lotion or after-shave oil that will help keep your legs smooth. It also softens the hair, leaving you less exposed to infections that are caused by hair getting trapped below the skin.

steps.title: Stop the bleeding of any cuts with petroleum jelly.
steps.content: Stop the bleeding of any cuts with petroleum jelly. If you did happen to nick yourself shaving, it’s easily fixed. Razor cuts are difficult to stop bleeding, but if you dry the area and dab on some petroleum jelly, the bleeding will stop.

steps.title: Treat razor burn.
steps.content: Treat razor burn. If you’ve wound up with the tell-tale red bumps of razor burn, take care to treat it, so the bumps don’t turn into scars. Put a warm compress on the area, which will relax the hair that’s trapped below the skin of the bump. [8] X Research source tell-tale sign of razor burn, bumps on your legs,

steps.title: Replace your blades regularly.
steps.content: Replace your blades regularly. You should replace your razor at the first sign of dullness, which usually occurs between 5 to 10 shaves. Shaving with a dull razor will lead to razor burn. Old blades are also more likely to trap bacteria and cause infections. [9] X Research source
